frameset.note: Framed and reframed and reframed again on basis of much discussion about aspectual usages. Ugh.

example.name: plain old transitive
example.text: The Herald kept its old-time Hearst readership.

example.name: object control with sentential attribute
example.text: Ringers keep the bells sounding in the many belfries of East Anglia.
example.arg: [the bells][sounding in the many belfries of East Anglia]

example.name: object control with Adj attribute
example.text: The captain kept the crew loyal.

roleset.name: maintain some prepositional relationship

example.name: be careful with 'from'!
example.text: Growers can't always keep the worm from the apple.

example.name: keep from: quasi-aspectual
example.text: Japanese demand has kept the U.S. currency from *trace* plunging.

example.name: keep out
example.text: Britain kept light tanks out of the talks.

example.name: keep off
example.text: Keep your Foster Savings Institution off the federal budget deficit.

example.name: with attributive
example.text: The Fed kept inflation-fighting as its top priority.

roleset.note: This roleset shows some relationship between nouns or gerunds described by the preposition introducing the second noun, and the 'keep' is causing or maintaining that relationship.

roles.note: This is a complex preposition and takes NO ARGUMENT STRUCTURE!

example.name: keep with
example.text: ... in *trace=nothing* keeping with the reputation of the company.

example.name: keep pace
example.text: Newsweek keeps pace with its rival Time.

example.name: keep track
example.text: The state keeps track of the achievement-test preparation booklets.

example.name: keeping up with the Joneses
example.text: John can't keep up with Mary's rapid mood swings.

example.name: aspectual
example.text: State monopolies will keep on [*-1] stifling trade, ``free'' prices or not, until something else replaces them.
